This is not the first time that I hear people claiming that the Cajuns are exported Acadians. But the Cajuns were the French living in the French colony of Louisiana (it probably doesn't help that those maps show the Spanish controlling the region which only happened after the war). The Acadians were sent largely to the Carolinas and Georgia and the exportation took place before the war when Nova Scotia was ceded to the British in 1713. When the rest of Canada became British a lot of them actually returned. It's weird how little most Americans know about the continent before the revolution.

Also, for the general enjoyment-- I'm watching through these with my 6 year old, who is very interested in learning about history, but has like no context for any of this, so we pause it and I translate and fill in concepts and we discuss. In discussing slavery here, and why/how people were doing that, I think it finally clicked for her what it was and the injustice of people profiting from slave labor. (Previously, I don't think she understood the difference between "I have to go to work, so we have money to pay rent" and actual forced labor, and the violation of an individuals rights therein). The moment when it clicked, she goes "wait, wait, I think I get it. Those guys want to grow crops, but cause they're LAZY and MEAN, they make those people do it and if they don't they like, whip on their back and then they keep all the money?! That's not good. I wouldn't do that."

Nice work, but there are several errors:

First, the French and Indian War is NOT the same as the Seven Years' War. It was the North American theatre of the Seven Years' War, not the war itself. IIRC, the fighting in North America began two years before the larger war, which is explains the discrepancy of the Seven Years' War "actually lasting nine years."

Second, another factor in the Revolution, perhaps the biggest one, was the fact that the British Parliament tried to tax the colonies in order to pay off its debts from the Seven Years' War. But of course, the Patriots argued that this violated their rights as Englishmen because it was done without their consent (hence "taxation without representation.") This is an error by omisson, focusing on the secondary causes of the Revolution while ignoring the cause that was by far the biggest and most important one.

Third, the Patriots certainly DID believe in equality for all, at least more than the British did. In an early draft of the Declaration of Independence, Thomas Jefferson attacked King George III for permitting the slave trade and referred to slave auctions as places "where men should be bought and sold." The fact that he called them "men" clearly indicates he intended to include blacks when he said that "all men are created equal" earlier in the document. It was only at the insistence of Southern delegates at the Second Continental Congress that he removed this section.

And yes, I realize that Jefferson was a slaveowner himself, but not everyone who opposed the Atlantic slave trade was necessarily against slavery itself. The slave trade was actually banned in the US in 1808, nearly 60 years before the Thirteenth Amendment fully abolished slavery, and Congress passed this legislation with little controversy, as even many who were not necessarily anti-slavery were still horrified by the conditions on slave ships and the cruelty of traders to their captives. Likewise, their were already enough slaves and their descendants in the South at that time that most Southerners didn't care much about whether or not slaves could still be transported from Africa.

Elaborating on what you said about the Proclamation, Cherokees experienced a cycle where colonists kept overrunning Cherokee land, Colonial officials would demand that the Cherokees cede the land, and the Cherokees would end up complying since they couldn't get colonists off their territory. Then more colonists would overrun more Cherokee land, etc. "When the American Revolution began, most Cherokees sided with the king, who had issued the Proclamation, rather than the colonists, who violated it with impunity." (From The Cherokee Nation and the Trail of Tears.)

It's cool to watch this just after reading about it from a Cherokee perspective in _The_Cherokee_Nation_and_the_Trail_of_Tears. According to the book, the reason Cherokees sided with the French was that after a bunch of Cherokee warriors aided a Virginian expedition against the Shawnee (who were French-allied), many of them were killed by English frontiersmen on the way home, "setting off a chain of events that included the murder of Cherokee hostages by the English, the invasion and defeat of an English army, and the Cherokee capture of the English fort west of the mountains." The English then invaded the Cherokees and destroyed towns, fields, and granaries.

Why is it that Crash Course never mentions that Spain received Louisiana after the Seven Years War? More development arguably occurred in Louisiana under Spanish rule than under the French. Almost all of the historic buildings in New Orleans including most of the "French" Quarter were constructed under Spanish rule (mostly because the whole city burned down twice under their reign).
I know Spanish rule of Louisiana is generally a little known fact to most people; but if the Assassin's Creed series can make an entire game set in Spanish Louisiana, then an internet series that is supposed to teach history can include it to. The Crash Course World History on the Seven Years War even directly says that France kept Louisiana after the war until the Louisiana Purchase. They only received it back from Spain after the rise of Napoleon (Spain probably felt that "gifting" Louisiana back to France was a good way to prevent Napoleon's forces from invading Iberia. They were wrong.)

The Seven Years War, was not coursed by economics and it was far from being an exception in complex causation. It was coursed by the Prussian king Frederick the Great attacking the land belonging to the parents of King Louis XV's daughter-in-law who was distressed by it and the French king's famous mistress Madame de Pompadour, being lead by emotion rather than common-sense, persuading Louis to reenter armed conflict with the aim of making France great, in part motivated by personal loathing for the Prussians, in part stemming from their (the Prussians) Lutheranism and the additional fact that Frederick the Great had his troops roaming over catholic lands that nominally belonged to the Holy Roman Empire, who's Empress Marie Theresa sought to regain the territory taken by Prussia. The Franco-British colonial thing, raised here in this video only paved England's entry into the war on Prussia's side, as they were in 1756 united in shearing a common enemy; plus the King of England, George II, had been born and raised in Hanover, a close traditional ally of Prussia.

In the end, it was a war about land. It also set the stage for the American Revolution, 12 years later.

Not only were the Native Americans stuck with the British after the Seven Years War, the tribes that had been allied with European powers during the conflict (and had provided decisive and invaluable assistance) were left out of the Treaty of Paris, despite having been promised land and greater autonomy by the French.

They also already had more direct access to the riches of the Orient than the Western European superpowers through the Indian Ocean trade network. John mentioned it earlier. This was already making them pretty rich and reduced the incentive to sail halfway across the globe to duke it out with three more powerful empires with better supply lines to their established colonies. Hope this helps, and that I'm remotely right.

2) Geography. The Ottomans were situated in the eastern Mediterranean, and would have to sail through parts of that sea dominated by Spain, France and Britain, the major (naval) powers of the day, just to reach the Atlantic. It navy wasn't that great either and was mainly built for Mediterranean littoral operations. To colonise America, they would have had to sail an army there that they couldn't spare on ships they didn't have.

Two major factors:

1) The Ottoman Empire was a land-based empire that possessed a large swathe of the Middle East, Southeast Europe and North Africa. Its armed forces were mainly dedicated to remaining in charge in those areas, and its grip on them was often tenuous, what with rivalries with other major powers and local uprisings in its occupied territories. So its army was mainly bogged down with keeping the place an empire.
